arm_group.description: Incision and drainage performed after patient received placebo patch with injection of 1% lidocaine into the site of the abscess.
Incision and drainage performed after patient received active lidocaine/tetracaine patch and injection of 10cc of saline into site of abscess

brief_summary.textblock:
Local anesthesia used for incision and drainage of abscesses is known to be painful.

      We studied the analgesia provided by a lidocaine/tetracaine patch compared to injectable
      lidocaine during incision and drainage (I&D) of skin abscesses.

      Local injection of lidocaine provided similar analgesia compared to the lidocaine/tetracaine
      patch during I&D of skin abscesses in the Emergency Department. Pain at presentation and
      following the procedure was similar in both groups.

clinical_study.brief_title: Injectable Lidocaine Versus Lidocaine/Tetracaine Patch for the Incision and Drainage of Skin Abscesses

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Age>18 years

          -  Skin abscess in need of incision and drainage (judged by treating physician)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Allergy to lidocaine or tetracaine

          -  Non-intact skin

          -  Unable/unwilling to provide informed consent

clinical_study.official_title: Injectable Lidocaine Provides Similar Analgesia Compared to Transdermal Lidocaine/Tetracaine Patch for the Incision and Drainage of Skin Abscesses: A Randomized Controlled Trial

primary_outcome.description: VAS measured at each of the 3 time points noted above.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in VAS pain score over time
primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately prior to starting I&D (Time 0); 2-5 minutes after start of I&D (Time 1); within 1 minute of completion of I&D (Time 2)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Bio-equivalence Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
